titleStmt.title: On that Unparalleled Prince Charles the First, His Horrid Murder
Poem 8

encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be further explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character’s status as majuscule or minuscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Elemental edition: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Amplified edition: By Sarah C. E. Ross.

app.rdg: 26On that Unparralel’d Prince Charles the first. his Horrid Murtherin different hand from main scribe; originally written “Horred” with the “e” corrected to an “i”
On that Unparalleled Prince Charles the First, His Horrid MurderThis phrase was added, probably in Pulter’s hand.

On that Unparalleleda common superlative in Pulter’s poems, most commonly applied to Charles I and his associates. See, for example, the poem immediately preceding this one, On those Two Unparalleled Friends, Sir George Lisle and Sir Charles Lucas. Prince Charles the First, His Horrid Murderthese words have been added to the title in a hand that is different from the main scribe’s, and may be Pulter’s own (see Ross (2000), pp. 150-171 and 252-4).

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.

note.p: My priority in editing these poems has been to modernise, and to achieve interpretative and visual clarity, in order to make the poems as accessible as possible to as wide a modern audience as is possible. Spelling is modernised, as is punctuation. Modernising the latter, in particular, often involves a significant act of editorial interpretation, but in my view this is one of the most productive areas of editorial intervention, particularly for a manuscript text such as Pulter’s where the punctuation is erratic compared to modern usage (and, indeed, compared to early modern printed texts).11. See Alice Eardley, “‘I haue not time to point yr booke … which I desire you yourselfe to doe’: Editing the Form of Early Modern Manuscript Verse”, in The Work of Form: Poetics and Materiality in Early Modern Culture, ed. Ben Burton and Elizabeth Scott-Baumann (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014), pp. 162-178.

In this edition of Poem 8, stanza breaks and numberings have been created based on marginal numberings and horizontal lines (at the ends of lines 8, 16, and 24) in the manuscript text. Like the addition of “His Horrid Murder” to the title (see notes), the numbers are in a hand that is different from the main scribe’s, and may be Pulter’s own.

rdg.note: This poem is one of several that meditates on the disastrous results caused by the death of King Charles I in the English Civil War. Offering an extended analogy, the speaker compares the national, natural, and personal trauma caused by the 1649 regicide to the trauma of the sun being extinguished. Written in iambic pentameter couplets, the poem draws heavily on mythological and cosmological knowledge, showing the relatively harmless consequences of losing particular constellations in the sky (compared to the disappearance of the sun’s primal heat and light). It concludes with a single couplet imploring God to install Charles II on the throne.

note.p: This poem is one of many that Pulter wrote on the fate of Charles I, from his imprisonment in 1647 until his execution and beyond. Some of these poems are elegies, and participate in the outpouring of elegiac literature on his death: see On the Horrid Murder of that Incomparable Prince and Let None Sigh More for Lucas or for Lisle [On the Same [2]], as well as the politicised insertion into her elegy on the death of her daughter, Jane Pulter (Upon the Death of my Dear and Lovely Daughter, Jane Pulter). For royalist elegiac literature and a reading of Pulter’s poems in this context, see Sarah C. E. Ross, Women, Poetry, and Politics in Seventeenth-Century Britain (Oxford UP, 2015), pp. 153-7; Robert Wilcher, “Lamenting the King: 1649”, in The Writing of Royalism, 1628-1660 (Cambridge UP, 2001), pp. 287-307; and Nigel Smith on royalism and elegy, in Literature and Revolution in England, 1640-1660 (Yale UP, 1994), pp. 287-294.

This particular poem, however, is less elegiac in tone than several of Pulter’s others: it focuses less on grief and consolation than on a cosmological comparison between the sun and Charles I. Each of the eight-line stanzas follows the same structure: the first four lines describe a (lesser) celestial splendour, before there is a turn at the fifth line to the greater splendour of the sun, which is a figure for the monarch. The final stanza has an additional four lines extending the political implications of the metaphor. This common association of the sun and the monarch undergirds many of Pulter’s poems, often in a further association of sun-king-Christ; see, for example, Let None Sigh More for Lucas or for Lisle [On the Same [2]], lines 38-45.

Pulter’s deep interest in cosmology and its metaphorical potential is evident throughout her work. See, for example, The Revolution, The Center, her two poems titled Aurora [1], Aurora [2], and A Solitary Complaint.

app.rdg: Thosein left margin, in lighter ink and different hand from main scribe: “(1)” glittring Globes of light which grace
Those glittering globesstars, planets of light which grace
Those glittering globes of light which grace
The vast Expantion, when they leave theire place
The vast expansionheaven, firmament, when they leave their place,
The vast expansion, when they leave their place
Or hide theire Radiant heads, wee never wonder
Or hide their radiant heads, we ne’er“never” in the manuscript wonder;
Or hide their radiant heads, we never wonder;
Theire place and Splendenti’s Supplied’e by number
Their place and splendency’s supplied by numberTheir presence and splendor are assured by their multitude, even if some disappear from view..
Their place and splendency’s supplied by numberI.e., the splendour of the stars and planets in the sky is created by their sheer number..
But Should the Sun forſake the line Ecliptick

But should the sun forsake the line eclipticthe great circular path of the celestial sphere that the sun appears to follow over the course of a year (as seen from Earth); named as such because eclipses can happen only when the moon is very near this line,
But should the sun forsake the line eclipticits orbit (OED ecliptic B.n.1) or apparent orbit as viewed from the earth,
Then totall Nature would be Epiliptick
Then total Nature would be epileptichave a seizure.
Then total nature would be epilepticin the manuscript, this is “epiliptic”, in a full rhyme with line 5;
Just so’s our caſe Since Royall Charles did die
Just so’s our case since royal Charles did die;

Just so’s our case since royal Charles did diePerhaps an allusion to the death of Christ, at which “the earth did quake, and the rocks rent” (Matthew 27:51). Pulter frequently uses the sun as a simultaneous figure for Charles (and his restoration) and Christ (and his resurrection).;
In horrid, Trembling Trances now wee liehorizontal line in lighter ink underneath
In horrid, trembling trances now we lie.
In horrid, trembling trances now we lie.
Coyein left margin, in lighter ink and different hand from main scribe: “(2)” Aſaph may her Sparkling Spendlor hide
Coy Asophcomet visible every 400 years may her sparkling splendor hide
Coy Asopha comet thought to be visible from earth every four hundred years may her sparkling splendour hide
&ff;our hundred years, yet wee noe change abide
Four hundred years, yet we no change abide;
Four hundred years, yet we no change abide,
And ^if Sad Electra may her bevties turn

And if sad Electraone of the Pleiades, or constellation of seven stars; mythical ancestor of the Trojans, known as the “Lost Pleiad,” or she is said to have disappeared before the Trojan war to avoid seeing the ruin of her beloved city; reputed to show herself occasionally to mortal eyes only in the guise of a comet; not to be confused with the daughter of Agamemnon and Clytemnestra, sister of Orestes who persuaded her brother Orestes to kill Clytemnestra and Aegisthus (their mother’s lover) in revenge for the murder of Agamemnon may her beauties turn
And sad ElectraIn Greek mythology, Electra, grieving for the destruction of Troy (Ilium) and the death of her son, is transformed into a comet. may her beauties turn
Away from us, yet non but Illium burn
Away from us, yet none but IliumTroy burn.
Away from us, yet none but Ilium burn.
But if the ſun in darknes be involv’d
But if the sun in darkness be involvedentangled, enveloped
But if the sun in darkness be involved,
Ould Natures fabrick would bee ſoon diſſolv’d
Old Nature’s fabric would be soon dissolved.
Old nature’s fabric would be soon dissolvedreduced to its elements, broken up (OED 1) ;
E’ne ſoe (Aye mee) ſince Sacrid Cæſars death
E’en so (ay me) since sacred Caesar’sepithet for King Charles death
E’en so (aye me) since sacred Caesaran epithet for Charles I, used by Pulter in many of her poems’s death
Our Spirits exhale in Sighs wee turn to earthhorizontal line in lighter ink underneath
Our spirits exhale in sighs; we turn to earth.
Our spirits exhale, in sighs we turn to earth.
Thoſein left margin, in lighter ink and different hand from main scribe: “(3)” Oviparos“O” possibly changed to “o,” or reverse Brothers Soe ador’d

Those oviparous brothersThe twins, Castor and Pollux, were born out of a single egg (“oviparous” means egg-laying, which Pulter uses idiosyncratically); Zeus transformed the twins into the constellation Gemini, which navigators use to track their course., so adored

Those oviparous brothersCastor and Pollux, twins in Greek mythology who hatched out of an egg (Pulter misuses “oviparous”, which means egg-laying). Zeus transformed them after their death into the constellation Gemini, used by navigators to find their way. so adored
By Navigators, would bee deplor’d
By navigators, would be deplored
By navigators, would be deploredlamented
By non but them nor doe wee care or feare
By none but them, nor do we care or fearfear if
By none but themi.e. the navigators, nor do we care or fear
The one or both of them at once apeare
The one, or both of them, at once appear;
The one or both of them at once appear.
But if the ſun Should loſe his heat and light
But if the sun should lose his heat and light
But if the sun should lose his heat and light
Wee Should invaded bee with Death and Night
We should invaded be with Death and Night.
We should invaded be with death and night;
Soe Since our Martred Sover’ngs Spirits fled
So since our martyred sovereign’s spirit’s fled,
So since our martyred sovereign’s spirit’si.e. spirit is/has fled

rdg.seg: Our light, and life; our hopes, and Joyes, are deadthe three commas in this line are added in a different ink

app.rdg: Our light and life, our hopes and joys, are dead.
Our light and life, our hopes and joys, are dead.
Nayin left margin, in lighter ink and different hand from main scribe: “(4)” Should the Poles or Axes of the Skie

Nay, should the poles or axes of the sky“Poles” are the points in the celestial sphere about which stars appear to revolve or the points at which the earth’s axis meets the celestial sphere; “axis” is the imaginary line about which planets rotate.
Nay, should the poles or axes of the skyAxes are the (imaginary) lines around which planets rotate, and the poles are the ends of these axes (see OED pole n.2 1a).
Their Raidient luster unto us denie
Their radiant luster unto us deny,
Their radiant lustre unto us deny,
Or Cinthia ceaſe to wane or to increasſe
Or Cynthiamoon, named after goddess cease to wane or to increase,
Or Cynthiathe moon cease to wane or to increase,
Wee Should Subsist, t’wold not diſturb o: r Peace
We should subsist; t’would not disturb our peace.
We should subsist, ’twould not disturb our peace.
But Should wee looſe the influence of the Sun
But should we lose the influence of the sun
But should we lose the influence of the sun,
All into Chaos inſtantly would run
All into chaosprimordial matter, nothingness instantly would run.
All into chaos instantly would run;
Soe Since our king’s aboue in glorys Crownd
So since our king’s above—in glory’sglory is crowned—
So since our king’s above in glories crowned,
Anarchicall confution doth Surround
Anarchical confusion doth surround
Anarchical confusion doth surround
This fatall Isle and Devils here will dwell
This fatal isleEngland, now doomed , and devilsusurpers led by Cromwell here will dwell,

This fatal isleEngland, condemned by fate, and devils here will dwellEardley (ed.),Lady Hester Pulter, suggests a reference to the race of rebellious giants thought to have populated the earth in ancient times, in Sandys, Metamorphoses, 1; and Ovid, Metamorphoses 1.151-160. See also Pulter’s Mighty Nimrod (Emblem 1), lines 11-17.,
As Antiantly and turn this place to Hell
As ancientlyin ancient times, and turn this place to hell.
As anciently, and turn this place to hell,
Unles our God doth a ſecond Charles illustrate
Unless our God doth a second Charles illustrateillumine or confer honor on the son of Charles I,
Unless our God doth a second Charles illustratemake illustrious, confer honour upon (OED v. 4)
Which (oh denie not) all our hopes are frustrate.
(Which, O deny not!) all our hopes are frustrate.
(Which, O deny not) all our hopes are frustrate.

milestone.rend: two ascending lines, in darker and lighter ink
